reviewText: Now I cannot comment on the eight minutes of film that was cut from this DVD release, for I have only seen this version of the film.  This film was raved upon raved by friends of mine and so, despite their apparent disgust with Lionsgate for cutting eight minutes from the opening sequences, I had nothing to be disgusted about.This film was beautiful.The film, told nearly in real time (an hour and a half film for an event that probably doesn't last more than three or four hours), `The Dead' takes place over a single evening where three sisters throw a Christmas dinner banquet for friends and family.  While the guests are all unique in themselves, it is one couple that takes the center of our focus; Gretta and Gabriel Conroy.  Over the course of the dinner (complete with dancing and singing and lots of drinking) the friends converse on many subjects, and they all reminisce about friends they've loved and lost.  In his closing speech, Gabriel touches upon this very notion and addresses the impact those `dead' have on the living.And then Gabriel's whole world is tossed on its head thanks to a secret memory his wife decides to share.Leaving the revelation to the films final frames was an act of genius.  I remember watching the film in full anticipation for the blow (for it is a detail that seems to be wildly spoiled, even in the production notes) but what I found so moving was that it isn't the actual memory that delivers the blow, but the way in which Gabriel allows that single `reality' to unravel his very own feelings and opinions.  As the film drifts off into its inevitable end, we listen as Gabriel self destructs.It's heartbreaking, to say the least.As an ensemble, the entire cast really shines in delivering a collective and cohesive understanding of the films purpose, but it is definitely Anjelica Huston and Donal McCann that take `best in show' accolades.  Huston's final breakdown is monumental in itself, but like McCann, she shines most when allowing the subtle weight of the evening to affect her.  McCann is simply divine here.  I have always had a soft spot for the male standouts in films (which is why I tend to gravitate toward predominantly male-driven dramas, as apposed to most of my friends who practice Actress Worship), and McCann instantly caught my eye and held my attention with his beautifully natural and almost otherworldly portrayal of a simple man contending with a seemingly simple evening.  Every moment he is on screen you can see him observing and taking in everything around him, and reacting to it.  It is a small and quiet performance, but his stare is enough to evoke many emotions from me.  Those eyes are just, well, I remember them well.  Those are the same eyes that stole all of my attention while watching `Stealing Beauty' in 1996.In the end I will forewarn.  Some may have an issue with the films structure and apparent lack of plot.  Like I said, the films only real revelation is exposed in the final scene.  Everything leading up to that scene, while intoxicatingly beautiful, could be deemed by some as boring and uneventful.  You are basically watching a group of friends share a dinner together.  That said, the film is ripe with rich character development and sheer poignancy.  For those willing to look deeply into what is presented, there are wonderful rewards to be found.Also, this is director John Huston's final film, so that is incentive enough for me.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Having had the VHS version of The Dead for many years, I was happy to see the DVD version finally being released after all these years- so I pre-ordered it.  I just sat down to watch it again and was very disappointed to see that the film had been cut, with several scenes deleted.  In particular, they must have decided they wanted to practically cut Donal Donnelly's Freddie Malins character out of the movie, as they cut two scenes early in the movie that provided great (drunken) comic relief- his entrance and bathroom scene ("anything under a mile and he'd miss the finish") the racing discussion and story Freddie tells of 'old man gallaher' and the girl practicing with a piglet story.As the film is a slice of life story centered on a dinner party in 1904 Dublin, it is a pity these scenes and other bits were cut.  I don't see any reason for the cuts- it's not like this was a long film to begin with, or that they needed to cut it to fit it on a single DVD.A great film has been cheapened by Lionsgate.  They, or someone else more capable, should provide a full-length version of this movie to do justice to John Huston as his last film.  They should also offer a free exchange for those unfortunate enough to buy this version thinking it was a full-length version of the film.

reviewText: Many of you are reading this five-star review because you love the original masterpiece as much many thousands of people do. I do, too.Be advised, however, that Lionsgate has issued this seriously abridged version (76 minutes) without any note of abridgment. Please contact Lionsgate to request a resissue of the full version. This is not the complete film.If you purchased your copy from Amazon, inform Amazon customer service of the problem. Amazon has never failed to help me with product issues, and I'm confident they'll help customers manage this one.John Huston's final masterpiece deserved better treatment than this.

reviewText: Can a very powerful and moving 10-minute scene redeem another 70 minutes of rather slow, not very interesting movie making? A woman sings a song at a Christmas dinner party which reminds Anjelica Huston of a long-dead lover. Later she confesses to her husband the intensity of this love of long ago (he wanted her to go away with him but she wouldn't go and he died). The husband is shocked by this confession because of the intensity of her feelings, even as they exist only in her memory. (Their married life has been pretty staid.) It's this confessional scene and its results that are so powerful and moving. But the rest? John Huston's last movie.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Considered by most critics as John Huston's last masterpiece, I think it's very good, but not deserving that high rank. First of all one has to read the original story, because of the lack of action everything is very subtle, everything happens as an undercurrent. One hints only at things for they exist no longer except in the minds of the people gathered here. Besides, those things belong in the past. They are memories, lost loves, lost youths and fond memories all. Dublin lives in the past, among the dead. All Dublin except for Gabriel (the alter ego of Joyce himself), who wants out of this Irish cemetery, even to the risk of being labeled a Brit. What's Galway compared to the continent? But his emigrating will have more than social repercussions. He has to consider his wife, who also belongs in the world of the past through the remembrance of her young lover, of long ago.Luckily for Joyce, his wife (when they left Ireland they were still unmarried) wasn't like that. He had his Nora with him, and they were of the same thinking. But that was unusual in those times, breaking away with traditions and conventions.There's a lot to learn from these kind of films. We in Spain can relate also, in this time when regional clans and their nazionalism pulls us apart for the sake of their mythical past and local heroes, and poisons us politically filling us with hatred towards one another, what is best to do? To search for ghosts of the past and live  quixotically, or to break away from the political-correct oppression of social-nazionalism and emigrate to... where? Don't give in to what people say is the truth. Find out for yourself.By the way, I figured out why I couldn't like the film as much as i wanted to (after watching it for the third time): I don't like very much the way Angelica Huston plays Gabriel's wife. It's just not convincing at all. Everybody else is wonderful, though.
summary: A great adaptation of James Joyce's short story

reviewText: If you are looking for drama, excitement or suspense, this movie will prove very disappointing.  In fact, the bulk of the film deals with a group of endearing and quirky characters having a grand old time at a 1904 Dublin dinner party, where sentimentality, drinking, poetry readings and maudlin ballads prevail.  In one brief moment, a couple engages in a sad pensive conversation. And that's really not enough to carry this film.
Title: N/A

reviewText: John Huston's "The Dead" vies, in my estimation, with "The African Queen" as his best movie, in this case, his last. As James Joyce's story, which this is a faithful adaptation of, is a favorite of mine, I was delighted and relieved on my first viewing how Huston got so much of it perfectly right.It is a tale of the Irish at a certain place and time, a tale of blindness, figuratively speaking, and a tale of lost love, lost twice over.There are two moments of epiphany in this film - the ballad overheard on the stair and that sad snow faintly falling - that captures the explicitly stated aim of Joyce's prose. You will be left at the end - as one always is in the presence of great works of art - moved, grateful and not quite the same.Addendum: If the release is as bad as the other revieweres say, I agree about boycotting this release. The movie, however, is magnificent when ALL of it is included.Addendum No. 2: Call Lionsgate Customer service to exchange your defective copy.
summary: How to correct the error: An Irish Beauty

reviewerName: F. J. Harvey "Cricket ,country music and a go...
reviewText: " Better pass boldly into that  other world in the full glory of some passion ,than fade and wither dismally from age "These words are taken fron James Joyce's short story " The Dead "which many regard as the best short story evr written in the English language .They belong to a middle-aged man ,Gabriel Conroy ,and they occur to him as his wife sleeps in a Dublin hotel room while snow falls across the whole of Ireland .They have spent the night of 6th January -Epiphany - at the home of his maiden aunts Julie (Cathleen Delaney)and Kate ( Helena Carroll) with the same group of old friends who gather there at the same time each year ;the routine is unvarying -they dine ,dance and regale each other with the same old stories ,usually of past nights at the opera  and tales of singers long since gone .The conversation reflects the role of the past on the present .The first hour of the movie is devoted to the party -its recitations ,its dances and songs and its same old embarrassments --Freddy Malen ( Donal Donnelly)gets drunk as he does every year to the anger of his fiercely upright mother .This year there is some hint of change in the air with some talk of the gathering Irish Republican movement .Then we switch to Gbriel and his wife Gretna as they drive across snow covered Diublin to their hotel ,in a horse drawn carriage .She tells him ,when they arrive at the hotel why it was that a particular song heard at the party moved her so .It reminded her of a boy who loved her when they were both 17 -a Michael Fureywho died of illness while tragically young .He pleaded with her not to go to Dublin to attend convent school but to stay and marry him .He stood outside her window in the winter rain ,caught a chill and died .Gabriel is moved by the tale and reflects as his wife lies sleeping that he has never really known his wife .He cries and his tears are for a man his wife once loved ,a man he never knew and has only just heard about .They are tears for the human condition -in giving us consciousness  God gave us the ability to know loss and to mourn it .The part shows us the commonplaces of a prosperous lifestyle -the last sequence depicts the hidden depths of loneliness and passion that exist secretly in the hearts of people we think ,erroneously ,that we know .The words that headed my review are pertinent -it is tale of passion ,hidden and poetic rather than destructive .It is the last movie John Huston made -he knew he was dying and it is a deeply personal project by a man who all his life was a passionate Hibernophile and it stars his daughter Angelica as Gretna as well as being scripted by his son Tony .It is not a wholly realised movie but rather a grand gesture -a great man's farewell to the medium he loved and the nation where he made his homeAs the silent snow falls on Ireland and the young Michael Furey ,so too it falls on the last resting place of John Huston who with this farewell gave us the opporunity-rare in cinema to revel in great prose spoken by those who know how to speak it .A quiet and profound pleasure

One comment I hadn't heard when I saw it was that everyone who's discussed at this Christmas dinner party is dead.  You have to be Irish to understand that.  It's the same logic that makes the obituary column be nicknamed, "The Irish funny papers."

reviewText: The last film of John Huston, the great American director of the Irish descent is an adaptation of the last short story in the early collection "Dubliners", of the greatest writer ever came from Ireland. The film is a family affair. The dying director made it based on the script adapted by his son Tony Huston from one of the most poignant, beautiful and profound short story ever written in this language and considered by many THE BEST English language short story. John directed his daughter Anjelica in what could be her finest screen performance. The film is short, only 83 minutes. It's got no action sequences, no plot, it is almost non-eventful, and it may seem slow. The guests, friends and relatives come to the party that takes place in Dublin during the Epiphany week in January 1904, at the house of two elderly sisters who give annual dinner with music and dance. What viewers see for the first hour, is the ensemble conversation piece. The guests talk, listen to the music, discuss the latest opera premiere, and make jokes, sometimes awkward. Gradually, the conversation turns to the long dead friends or relatives the memory of whom never faded away.This is the film you have to stay with, let it pull you in, listen to what and how the guests at the party say, how they communicate. Pay attention to the body languages, to the looks at their faces when they drift away from the light, laugh, and music of the present to the long gone but never in fact left most precious memories where the Dead of the title are not dead but forever young and so alive. If you do, you will be awarded with the final scene of such emotional power and impact that it will always stay with you. It will break your heart to pieces, pull them together and put it back transfixed. The film as well as Joyce's story centers on Gabriel Conroy (Donal McCann as James Joyce's alter ego gave a very moving understated performance) as one of the party guests who arrives with his wife Gretta (Anjelica Huston). Gabriel is still in love, feels close connection to and fascinated with her. It is after the party, he discovers that even after many years of closeness, he does not know all about her past, her pains, her regrets, and the unforgettable emotions and loss she had lived through as a young girl, and he is no part of. For the first time, he looks at her and thinks of her not as the indelible part of his existence but as another human being with her own inner world, her own loneliness and sadness, and for the first time, "a strange, friendly pity for her entered his soul." It is he who narrates the final most powerful and profound lines of the story: "Snow is general all over Ireland. . . falling faintly through the universe, and faintly falling, like the descent of their last end, upon all the living and the dead."If you have not seen the film or read the Joyce's story, please do. They are truly the works of Art that leave the everlasting impression and would change something in you to the best.
summary: "Think of all those who ever were, back to the start of time..."

reviewText: The best film ever produced; flawless directing and astonishing acting. A perfect poem. John Huston felt this his finest moment and I could not agree more. I rate it over Amarcord, Seven Beauties, Billy Elliot, History Boys and other finest literary moments. HOWEVER, after waiting more than a dozen years for the DVD to be produced, lo and behold it is missing one of the finest scenes in the film--a scene which defines the drunken nephew (one of the truly great all-time performances). Some idiot lost the scene in the editing room, and the studio was too dim and tired to bother to match up the segment from video. Evil on Lionsgate, they have emasculated a classic! I recommend buying the VHS and having it converted.

reviewText: John Huston's adaptation of The Dead (screenplay by son Tony Huston) is a breathtaking success.  The day Lionsgate announced their release of the film in its correct 1.85 ratio I pre-ordered twelve copies, eleven to be given to friends.  Regrettably, all twelve discs will be returned to Amazon because Lionsgate arbitrarily deleted 10 minutes of footage from The Dead's first act.  What the hill did they expect to gain by condensing a masterpiece with an original running time of just 83 minutes?  Idiots.This is not Amazon's crime.  Returning these discs is an action I wish weren't necessary.

reviewText: For starters....I recently rented this film from netflix, and it's the original film.  Lionsgate, the distributor of this DVD, stupidly cut the first 10 minutes of the film due to a "production error", but since have reissued it at its proper length.  Honestly, in this day and age such egregious (or lazy) errors like that are inexcusable.  The movie going (and DVD buying) public are far too sophisticated to let something as idiotic as shaving off the first 10 minutes of any film to go unnoticed.  There is no excuse for this type of professional sloth (especially on such a treasured film such as John Huston's The Dead), and I hope that in the future that this will not occur again.Now onto the review....This is a magnificent, ruminative, deeply moving, sad, dark, and haunting film, one of John Huston's finest achievements and, honestly, one of the most unique, startlingly original films I've ever seen.  It's a complete turn around from most of Huston's previous work, in fact, it's almost a new beginning for a new path had John Huston lived on.  The only 2 films I can compare it to are another Hollywood master's final film, Seven Women, directed by John Ford, in that Seven Women was unlike anything Ford had done before, and is one of the most unique films.  The Dead is almost reminiscent of Luchino Visconti's final film, The Innocent.  The Dead and the Innocent (great title for a new film, eh) are both tragic, sad, filled with exquisite performances, set design, cinematography, and the like.  They were the final films of 2 great directors, and both directors were in wheelchairs when they directed what turned out to be their final films.Huston's The Dead is a beautifully realised chamber piece by John Huston.  I watched this film when it came out on VHS oh so long ago.  I was ridiculously young at the time, and while I was respectful (and especially liked the ending), I didn't fully get it.  The Sundance Channel has been playing it quite a bit lately, so when it came out on DVD (in a proper version), I was so happy to see it again.  It plays so much better now, operating on many deeper levels than I couldn't have understood when I was younger.  Even though I viewed it last night, it's still haunting me.  It's like a distilled moment in time, still alive in your memory yet far away too.  I adore this film.  Many old Hollywood masters (of which Huston was one) didn't survive too well when the studio system faded away (like Billy Wilder and Vincent Minelli for example), but somehow Huston did.  His final works (Prizzi's Honor, Under the Volcano, and this film) rank amongst his finest work, or are at least as good as his more famous works.  The Dead is a remarkable achievement, a testament of one of Hollywood's finest (and underappreciated) filmmakers, and ranks as one of the most unique films from Huston's cannon.  A true masterpiece.
summary: A true masterpiece, one of Huston's greatest achievements, and one of the greatest final films by any director....

reviewText: The last Opus of a filmmaker is not always, successful. There are countless striking proofs that even many times the last farewell would seem to have nothing in common respect the artistic journey of the artist. If you glimpse the last sculptures of Michelangelo for instance (fabulous works mostly unknown) or the last Sonatas of Beethoven, you will ever experience a quantum leap, or a void leap; it depends in last instance of the personality of the creator.In the case of John Huston, I guess this work must have been a very fondled project from his early years; a sublime expression of the most pyramidal of his writers and thinkers, James Joyce is one of the supreme Giants of the literature and the inestimable specific weight of his thought must be a particular pride 's motive for Ireland.In this sense I think Huston planned to make the mythic Farewell: a party is given by three women for a group of dearest friends. But those people now dead, had a notable influence and repercussion on the lives of guests and hostesses at the party.Just a reduced number of filmmakers have enjoyed this special feat over the death: to say goodbye with a masterpiece. Buñuel, Jean Vigo, Visconti, Kurosawa and Huston may be proud to have done it.

reviewText: This was a delight to see, and a great achievement for John Huston in his twilight years.I can't express enough of my admiration for him for choosing to direct such a challenging story in the last year of his life.It's evident with his handling of the material, using such a heartfelt and admiring eye, that this story was near and dear to him.Some have stated the acting could be better, and although this may be true, in no way do any of the performances interfere or steal away from the story Joyce created or Huston so eloquently filmed.Another thing that is in evidence is that the film elaborates on the atmosphere and the individual partygoers in a way the short story couldn't do, due to scope and POV.A real treat for Joyce fans and fans of John Huston's work. Much admiration.Enjoy!
summary: A Must for Fans of Joyce's Short Story and John Huston's Direction

reviewText: Why is it such a gem of a movie is so difficult to obtain?I saw the scene of Anjelica Huston on the stairs when I was in college (the professor showed it to us when teaching "Dubliners").  I later decided to rent it and was happy with it.This year, before my first day of work (I work in a school district), I treated myself to an Irish coffee and read "The Dead" before bed.  Forgetting how much I truly enjoyed this story, I decided that I must own the movie.I searched unsuccessfully throughout the area although did manage to secure a copy through Amazon.  What a treat to watch this visual masterpiece.  Although we do not have the benefit of Gabriel's musings until the end, we can see the pretentiousness and elitism, where his own image superscedes what is importance.  The dancing, music, conversation, and dinner are so mirthful, yet so very artificial.  Yet, it isin the hotel room after the party that reality thrust upon us.  The illusion of immortality is crushed as Gretta (Angelica Huston) shares the tragedy of a lost love.  One does not feel protected in the hotel room, one feels cold, much as it is outside in the snow.  The contrast, the emotions stirred, are so very tremendous that few movies are able to match.  Unfortunately, many will find the movie to be a sharp yawn and a prelude to falling asleep.  The thoughtful viewer (and pronounced James Joyce admirer) will see this as a treat to behold.  I am so very lucky to have this for my bookshelf and believe I shall treat myself to it quite regularly!

reviewText: "The Dead" is a DVD of James Joyce's short story of the same name.  It shows a dinner party of friends in Dublin in 1904.During the festivities, a husband sees his wife react deeply to an Irish song.  Later he finds she is still terribly tormented by an early love who died.  He reflects on how, though a good and loving man, he has never experienced love as she has.  It is a deeply moving story, contrasting the seemingly joys of daily life and relationships with the actual depths of loving experience perhaps only a few of us ever realize.  Anjelica Huston stars, directed by her father, John Huston.
summary: The fluff and the essence of life
Title: N/A

reviewText: A lovely final film in John Huston's great stretch of movies. Tender. Heartbreaking. Willing to let the story unfold in its own rhythm, he does right by the novelette...coming closer than any other director I've seen to capturing the tone of James Joyce's writing.It's s simple story -- a holiday party at the home of two spinster sisters, with good food, music, dancing, singing, and gossipy companionship, all in a bustling wintry evening. The central characters of Gabriel and Gretta are beautifully underplayed by Donal McCann and Anjelica Huston; the costuming, lighting and set design add to the ambience; the screenplay is neatly adapted from the book; but it's Huston's gentle touch that lets the movie sing.An elegant end to a great career in film.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is an outstanding film adaptation of James Joyce's story, and possibly one of the better film adaptations of any story. It's not an easy story to transfer to film, either. A few short lines between Gabriel and Gretta at the beginning clearly indicate the tension between them without belaboring the point. The dinner party scenes are masterful, with the same barely hidden tensions between the guests right below the surface, made apparent as they were in the original story, where what is not said is as important as what is said out loud. There are hints that the drunk Freddy Malins will do something awful, but instead, we only see a sad, alcoholic failure, more pitiable than dangerous. The brief scene between Gabriel and Miss Ivors hints at the historic events taking place in the characters' environment, while at the same time setting up the later references to Gretta's childhood in Galway. During the meal, someone mentions "a fine tenor," and if you know what to look for, this clearly reminds Gretta of something.At the close of the party, the remaining guests pause to listen to Bartell D'Arcy finally singing something, as it turns out, "The Lass of Aughrim," the same song Gretta's teenage lover sang. This is the final element of the film's masterful buildup to the climax, as all of the influences assemble to produce the final denouement. Joyce never again attained the same depth of emotion that he communicated at the conclusion of "The Dead." Huston conveys the same emotional depth in the film, although I'm not sure how it would come across to someone unfamiliar with the story.Several other reviewers have commented on scenes cut from the DVD, such as Freddy Malins' drunken entrance to the party. The Netflix version I saw included this scene, so I assume it was complete. Many films would be improved by having a few scenes cut; this is not one of them.
summary: The dead are more real than the living

reviewText: Everyone, myself included, is upset about the 11/3 Lionsgate release, altho I have to admit I've yet to watch my copy and was not aware of the missing minutes until I read a review of the DVD in last Sunday's  (12/26) New York Times.  The Times article included Lionsgate instructions for obtaining an 83-minute copy of the film and I've followed them, phoning and speaking with a Lionsgate customer service rep (Ms. Tessie) at 1-800-650-7099.  Per Ms. T., the company wants proof of purchase of the original release but they don't want the faulty copy. So I've complied.Don't know what will come of it, but, on December 30, as I write this, here's hoping.(On the other hand, anybody who pre-ordered from Amazon paid less than $9 for the DVD and Amazon is still selling it for less than $10.  And it's probable that most people who like the film are 1n an income bracket where $20 for a great movie is very reasonable.  I know, I know: IT'S THE PRINCIPLE OF THE THING!!!)And here I am again. It's now January 26, and I've just received the Lionsgate replacement DVD.  It's 83 minutes long (I checked it on my player), so I guess I should change my review to a 5-star which is definitely what the movie deserves.And, if anyone from Lionsgate reads this stuff, thanks for correcting the error.

reviewText: This is a beautiful film that I would recommend to those who have read Joyce's short story and those who have not.  This is one of the few instances where the visual medium enhances and even improves appreciation  of the original written work.  Set in 1904 in an elegant Dublin home on  Christmas Day, it is an extremely moving character study of a portion of  middle class Dublin society.  The characters are shown with their charms as  well as flaws intact, as the plot wends its way to the epiphany of Gabriel,  the main character, who comes to realize the many things he has never known  about his wife to whom he has been married many years.  Even the final  overwhelming soliloquy of melancholy of Gabriel's character is enveloped in  a deep and haunting Irish charm, and the result is magnificent.  A powerful  film that is a literate must see.

reviewText: THE 73 MINUTE WATERED DOWN TRAVESTY!!!  DO NOT BUY THIS VERSION, we're all better of buying it in person or from someone we can directly contact if possible.  Even the studio had to apologize to people for cutting the film down for no reason, but that apology obviously did not mean they stopped selling it.I am very upset that I actually sought out the proper 83 minute version of "THE DEAD" and received the 73 Minute Version anyway.  I actually spent an hour searching, trying to avoid the 73 minute version and decided on this purchase after obviously being misled by Amazon's description.I'm 99% certain individual sellers are not to blame rather Amazon's UPC system that most likely does not differentiate between the two versions since the re-release and original release do not have separate pages.OFFICIALLY AMAZON NEEDS TO MAKE AMENDS BY MAKING TWO SALE PAGES FOR BOTH VERSIONS, WE ARE ALL BEING MISLED AS TO WHAT PRODUCT WE WANT TO BUY AND WHAT WE ACTUALLY RECEIVE.Very upset.
summary: Advetrised as 83 Minute, I got the 73 Minute Version!
Title: N/A

reviewText: The last scene of "The Dead" includes a voice over by Donal McCann and just may be one of the most beautiful scenes I've ever seen. In retrospect it was the perfect way for John Huston to finish his long career. But before this scene, I found the movie challenging to sit through. The acting was superb but much like Huston's "Under the Volcano", the story seemed to meander along at a slow pace and and I lost my interest, hoping something would happen soon. My patience was rewarded in the last scene, but I think the movie would have been better as a short feature film (featurette) of perhaps 45 minutes. As it is, I can't give it more than 3 stars, but I'm still glad I saw it, and it should be on DVD.Update: the movie is available on a PAL region 2 DVD in the UK. It's for sale at amazon.co.uk
summary: Slow movie with a perfect ending.
Title: N/A

reviewText: 5/27/10 Addition:This is a message to all the third party sellers who advertise that they have a copy of this DVD for sale:  I have written to no fewer than eight (8) of you over the past several months, asking whether the copy(ies) you are selling is the 73 minute or 83 minute version of this film.  Thanks to one of the reviews on here, I was able to provide these third party sellers with the code number for the later released, corrected version.  Two sellers never bothered to answer me; the others just never bothered to check their stock, telling me in a pro forma response that "the version we have is what is described in the Amazon product description".That's not good enough.  Here's a simple request:  why not check your stock, and take a moment to indicate in your ads which version you are carrying?  If it's the corrected one,  most of us would buy a copy from you in an instant.  But nobody wants to end up with the wrong version of this DVD, just because you want to clear out some old, unwanted stock.---------------------------Rodney Dangerfield and Vito Corleone (and why not add Aretha Franklin to the mix) would agree:  John Huston, one of our finest American film directors, gets nothing but disrespect from the DVD industry.Two months ago, I received word, after years of waiting, that "The African Queen", one of the most popular and fun-filled adventure/romance classics of the 50's, was finally going to get a Region 1 DVD release.  That pre-release notification turned out to be premature, and "The African Queen" DVD release has again been shelved."The Dead", John Huston's final film, has never seen a Region 1 DVD release, so when this release was announced a few months ago, many Huston fans collectively jumped for joy.  So what does Lionsgate do?  They produce a shortened version of the film, deleting between 8 and 10 minutes.  I was fortunately able to avoid buying the DVD, thanks to the reviews which immediately cropped up on Amazon.  Lionsgate, after issuing a recall, promised that a corrected DVD would be released by the end of November.  I haven't held my breath.The five star rating here is for the original film only, with one star awarded to Lionsgate for this butchered mess.  This quiet, contemplative classic is by far the most faithful film adaptation of a Joyce work.  Scroll through the reviews on this page for the one written by "Mulkurul", which contains a youtube clip of one of the most sublime  moments ever captured on film:  Angelica Huston standing at the top of a staircase, lost in memory while listening to Frank Patterson's character singing "The Lass of Aughrim" in the adjoining room (and watch her husband watching her). The scene is spellbinding.Lionsgate:  coal in your stocking this year, and a big bah humbug, until you correct this mistake, and give this treasured American film maker the respect he deserves.
summary: No Respect - REVISED:  Message to Third Party Sellers 5/27/10

reviewText: Nov. 5, 2009 Update: LionsGate does the right thing and issues a replacement disc late in November with the missing footage.  They have posted their address and email for prior purchasers who have their receipt to be able to get a replacement copy. Thank you LionsGate for doing right by your customers!  The new disc is supposedly due before Thanksgiving.Original review: I saw a screening of "The Dead" at Columbia U in NYC.  It was a case of seeing the film before reading the short story in Joyce's classic "The Dubliners."  In many ways, I'm glad I did.  John Huston, an Irishman, cast his daughter Anjelica in this faithful and reverent adaption that would be his swan song as a director.  The Dead starts slowly as a lovely family Christmas tale and builds to what I would consider a shattering conclusion.  Anjelica Huston's performance in this small film is powerful and has stayed with me since I first saw it. It's a film worth watching at least once a year, perhaps in combination with the short story.  I have the overseas DVD release from Vestron.  The picture is quite poor. So it's a treat that this small masterpiece is finally getting the respect it deserves.  Everyone should order a copy of this film and watch it during the Feast of the Epiphany :)
summary: Saints be praised! :)  John Huston's treatment of this classic Dubliner's tale.  11/5/09 Update: LionsGate is issuing new DVD!
Title: N/A

reviewText: In 1987, John Huston filmed his 'swan song', a portion of James Joyce 's 'Dubliners'. Mr. Huston was dying, he went to Ireland to shoot this film, and it is a sublime beauty. I started viewing this film without an understanding of the import and my reaction.I noted Anjelica Huston, as she first appeared in the film,what a beautiful woman,and how ethereal she appears. I say this, after watching Anjelica Huston in the TV series 'Smash' as a hard nosed producer, nothing soft and warm about that lady. Her face structure has even changed. This film is a gift of the Irish. A family dinner and dance and all the relatives have come to the home of their two Irish aunts to celebrate.  Dancing,singing, oratory and the ubiquitous drunken nephew are all part of the family. "He was not too bad, tonight" one of the Aunts mentions about the drunken Freddy. A turkey and pudding and, of course, all the drink one would want.As they are leaving Anjelica, known as Gretta stops on the stairway mesmerized by the song 'The Lass of Aughrim', in the carriage to the hotel, she tells her husband that a boy from Galway, that she once knew, used to sing that song. She fears he died because she was leaving home and leaving him.  And,as John Huston and James Joyce believed and said, " No matter how long in their graves, the dead will always influence the living. "Lovely, soothing memorable film.Recommended. prisrob 04-22-13
Title: N/A

reviewText: I'm not really sure why I like this movie so much.  Nothing much happens in it.  It takes place in Dublin on Twelfth Night (January 6) 1906.  The occasion is a holiday dinner party given by two elderly spinster sisters for friends and family. Anjelica Huston is the only name I recognize in the cast, but there are other fine actors who are obviously known in Ireland and elsewhere.  The acting is fine, and the singing and recitation and conversation are quaint.  I love Freddie the drunk who is nevertheless rather charming and touching. I guess I like it because it makes me feel warm and cozy, as though I am attending the party myself.  Doesn't hurt that I wrote my high school senior year term paper on "Dubliners" by James Joyce, the short story collection from which this story is taken.
Title: N/A

reviewText: To wait so long for the DVD release on this title and then to have this butchery of a fabulous film slipped in in its place...  I cannot express my anger in mere words.  I am only left to think that we as moderns look upon such instruments of medieval torture as the cat-o'-nine-tails as cruel and barbaric.  Hogwash!  Bring them back and use them on the idiots that slashed more than 10% of this film in ridiculous cuts.  I feel compelled to use a Ouija board to summon Dante to return and create another layer of Hell just for the occasion.The opening of the film surrounds Aunt Julia and Kate as they welcome guests to their annual Feast of the Epiphany, all the while dreading the arrival of their oft-besotted nephew Freddy, wondering if he will arrive sober or "stewed."  The next scene skips past Freddy's dubious arrival and we see him already at the party, sitting under the shriveling watch of his castrating mother.  It must get worse but I can't watch anymore.  This is going back to Amazon.  Tragically, the video quality is vastly superior to my old VHS versions but they will have to live a little longer until some real studio chooses to do this job right.  STAY AWAY FROM THIS VERSION!!!!!
summary: Unacceptable!  Inexcusable!  I hate being forced to give it one star.

reviewText: 01-27-2010 NOTE: Liongate has replied to my email, and has promised to send a replacement. They have not specified a date. Since it appears the "new" version is not yet for sale on amazon, I am not holding my breath, but it is heartening to see they have responded as they have.12-28-2009 NOTE: The NY Times reports Lionsgate acknowledges the missing 10 minutes (a production error), and will will provide a replacement (83 minutes) for those who purchased the 73 minute version. Details by sending an email to [...]  or 800-650-7099I have not contacted them yet, but thought I should add this information right away, for those who like me, love this film.As today this dvd is not available directly from Amazon, I presume they are awaiting the new 83 minute edition before they relist it for sale.MY ORIGINAL REVIEW:I'm terribly  biased toward this film. One of those that either grabs you, or bores you til your eyes roll back in your head. If youre looking for a plot, theres not much to summarize: you'll get an intimate look at a 1904 Christmas party in Dublin. Little happens. But much is revealed as this Christmas Eve passes. The attendees are a cross-section of (mostly)  Catholic Dubliners. Joyce is quoted in the last few minutes of the film, in a very  memorable scene.One reviewer here mentions several minutes of the original film were cut in this recent dvd transfer  This film was only available (in the USA) on vhs  until recently.  Both the ntsc and 2006 pal dvd  versions sold on amazon (and amazon uk)  show the running time as 83 minutes. An old vhs tape selling  on amazon.uk  shows the time as 79 minutes, so I'm  a bit confused. If it has been cut, its a shame; this one could be 4 hours longer, and I wouldnt mind.The incidental music is wonderful too. Incidentally, a Broadway musical of this short story ran briefly back in the '90s. I would love to see the full score of that show released, though I fear its not worth the expense for the producers, since cast recordings generally dont sell well.This is John Huston's last film. His daughter Angelica is a member of the magnificent ensemble cast.

reviewText: Do not buy this video if you do not enjoy movies made with delicacy and wistful melancholy -- it is short, has no real plot and features no special effects.  Yet this movie stands as one of the best ever -- it weaves a  spell over you, and captivates your every sense.  We are treated to the  visual trimmings of a holiday feast, along with the Irish folk music that  will, just when you least expect it, turn your expectations upside down.  The lively characterizations of every player in this movie bring it to  vivid life; it's as if you have entered a Christmas card, and can taste,  smell and feel everything around you.  That James Joyce's story revolves  essentially around a simple, but devastating revelation, is what makes it  brilliant.  So many times in this movie the obvious gives way to more  specific visions: as one of the many, many colorful ladies speaks at her  party, we are brought inside a bedroom, where we linger with the camera on  objects -- picture frames, combs, etc., that spark the imagination and  underscore the proceedings with a singluar clarity. Angelica Huston is  magically compelling, and the final monologue, delivered with subtle power,  will haunt your memory.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Sheer perfection. Director John Huston's final motion picture ends on a haunting, spellbinding note - a parting glance at his love for Ireland. Based on a James Joyce short story, "The Dead" (1987) is an intimate and finely drawn portrait of a post-Christmas family gathering in 1904 Dublin. It's one of the rare Huston films that displays a meticulous penchant for ensemble acting. Running 85 minutes, "The Dead" is over before you know it - as though you had a soulful holiday visit. The chilling climax reveals the words that provide a fitting coda to Huston's life and work: "Better pass boldly into that other world in the full glory of some passion than fade and wither dismally with age."

reviewText: The problem of "modern" Ireland has always been the hold that the past exerts over the present -- see something similar in the novels of Faulkner and certain cultural attitudes in the American South even today.  Joyce's triumph here -- or one of them -- is to render that trope in terms of the strains within a personal relationship.  Gabriel Conroy likes to think of himself as a "modern" man, and yet he ends up feeling inferior and defeated before an image from the past sparked by his wife's memory of a young boy who was infatuated with her.  There's a lot more than just that going on, of course, and viewers of the movie should read the story too.  The director, John Huston, whose last movie this was, makes a number of interesting changes to the events in the story as told by Joyce.  I want to mention just two.  In the story, Gabriel's old Aunt Julia, who is beginning to be fretful and forgetful, sings a song (she had been a notable singer earlier in her life), and despite her age, she sings it beautifully.  It's "Arrayed for the Bridal," a Bellini melody from "Puritani" and obviously sadly ironic, given Julia's age and spinsterhood.  In the movie, she sings it badly, though everyone flatters her and says that she sounds just fine.  Also, in the story, Bartell D'Arcy starts to sing "The Lass of Aughrim," but he is hoarse and has to break off.  He sings just enough to captivate Greta, Gabriel's wife, who associates the song with her long-ago admirer, a boy who died at 17.  In the movie, D'Arcy (played by the tenor Frank Paterson) sings the whole song beautifully, and the camera stays on the image of Greta listening for the whole period of the song.  In a sense, it's undramatic -- watching Greta (Anjelica Huston) listen.  But it's absolutely riveting, and sets up the ending, in a spirit faithful to Joyce, perfectly.  A very fine movie, then -- and great performances by Donal McCann and Anjelica Huston -- and all the others, for that matter.

reviewText: I am reminded somehow of "An Irish Airman Meets His Death" when I see this wonderful movie-tale. There is an inherent hesitation in its flow -- until the very ending, when Joyce reveals his simple thrust: there are more things in heaven and earth....The acting is superb.  A period-piece, each member of the cast fits into his/her place with perfection.  The themes before the End commemorate Humanity.  The End commemorates all of them together: lost (or unrequited) love.I love Irish music and its often heart-rending simplicity (some I know call it 'boozy sentimentality; I disagree).  This film has much music, sentimental, subjective and, yes, very, very subtle.  The admixture moves one's heart -- and, maybe, one's soul.This one should be in a thoughtful person's video archive.  On wintry nights, when the hearth has lessened to embers awaiting their deaths -- we ought to think of what this film has to say: to all of us.
summary: The Dead Are All Among Us

reviewText: Review of the restored, 83 minute version:Lionsgate has made good on its promise to supply uncut versions of this film to those who bought the truncated version, and if you were among the latter, I urge you to contact them immediately and get a proper copy of this film.  It's that good.  Seriously, the beauty of this film cannot be overstated, though if you're of a literal turn of mind, you might not appreciate it since, on the surface, it's a story about a lot of Irish people going to a party, talking about music and some of them drinking too much.But those with patience will see how this film is about the interior life, and particularly about the lives of women and the things which move them.  Down to the smallest detail, this film gives shape and weight to the lives of the women around whom the story revolves; the carefully preserved family mementos, the Bible and rosary, the delicate lace curtains all speak volumes about who they are, and what memories they keep locked away.The quality of the DVD is quite good now that it's been restored to its proper running time.  I was particularly pleased at being able to see so much of the detail of the costumes and sets which were much less clear in tape or broadcast versions, particularly as the details are just wonderful, thought out to the last bit of lace or delicate brooch.  To be blunt, I am so very happy to have this (whole) on DVD at long last that I could sing!The only fudge factor here is the cover, with Anjelica Huston's head superimposed (badly) on someone else's body (Her hed is pastede on, yay)  Given that the original release had a lovely cover, I have to wonder what the people at Lionsgate were thinking when they okayed this one.  It's a minor quibble, and under the circumstances, not something I'm going to subtract a star for (maybe half a one, if that was possible, which it's not) but it deserved mention.In short, I think Lionsgate has give us a quality product at last, and thanks to some serious complaining by those of us who love this film dearly.  Yes, I recommend it, now that it's been restored.---------------------One-star review of the truncated, 75 minute travesty:I have been waiting for a DVD release of "The Dead" almost since the day I first discovered the film at a tiny video rental store.  I fell immediately in love with the film and bought a copy for myself because I wanted to be able to watch it whenever I chose.Time passed.  Even more time passed.  DVDs which were just appearing on the horizon when I first saw this film eclipsed VHS but there was no sign of a release.  I managed to burn the movie to DVD, a hectic and not-terribly satisfactory solution.  When I discovered a PAL version was available I ordered it since I had a multi-standard DVD player.Why am I telling you all this?  Because I want you to understand how I felt when I found that Lionsgate was finally releasing "The Dead" to DVD in this country.  I was overjoyed, I pre-ordered it, and I waited anxiously for it to arrive.And then I watched it and nearly wept.  It's not bad enough that the beautiful cover of the original film has been replaced by hideous cover art with no real connection to the film, save the image of Anjelica Huston, but to find that an 83-minute film has been chopped down to 75 minutes, and utterly without regard for the continuity was enough to make me furious, and determined to keep anyone else from buying this travesty.Fortunately Lionsgate has apparently discovered that their truncated version of the real thing was not being well-received (What were they thinking??) and has issued a recall.  [...] They are taking the position that it was an accident.  My thinking is that an accident is not sending the DVD out in the case, or sending defective one, or sending ones with the wrong film.  Cutting a film to pieces is not an accident, it is a deliberate act.  I see from the information on IMDb that in Spain, the release is 79 minutes.It's not as if this is as long as say, "Fanny and Alexander"'s original version, or another "Lawrence of Arabia."  This is 83 minutes we're talking about.  If you don't have an attention span that long you won't like this film anyway, no matter how much they cut out of it.  This is a film that is short and perfect, and it should not be interfered with in any way.So if you were one of the unfortunates who bought a copy, please go to the URL I've just posted and get yourself a copy of the real (we hope) film before they say "Oh no, too late!" or do something else boneheaded to it.  And pass the word.  Lovers of this film have waited far too long to be jerked around like this.
summary: UPDATED: Two, two, two reviews in one!

reviewText: This was one of the first movies I ever saw Anjelica Huston, my favourite actress, in.  The movie is very faithful to the work of Joyce and for a rather short film, very emotional, powerful, and a true masterpiece, which just goes to show length doesn't necessarily mean good!  Beautiful costumes, stirring score, incredible acting, fantastic cast and very moving storyline.  Please put this Huston gem on DVD, where it belongs for all generations.

reviewText: I rarely think in such superlatives, but "The Dead," for my money, may be as close to perfection as film making gets.  The performances are so real, so natural, that it's hard to believe these are actors on the screen.  Angelica Houston, one of our most underrated actresses, is luminous.  I had never been a big John Houston fan until I saw this movie, but "The Dead" convinced me of his greatness.  I don't know what else to say to convey my love of this film.
summary: One of the All Time Greatest Films
